member.name: M:TALib.Candles.UpDownSideGapThreeMethods``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{System.Int32},System.Range@)
member.summary: Upside/Downside Gap Three Methods (Pattern Recognition)
member.param: A span of input open prices.
A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the output pattern type for each price bar.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Upside/Downside Gap Three Methods Pattern function identifies a bearish or bullish continuation pattern. This pattern typically occurs during a trend and consists of three candles where the first two are of the same color, followed by a third candle of the opposite color, with a noticeable gap between the first two candles' real bodies.
Calculation steps:
Verify that the first two candles share the same color (both white or both black).
Confirm a gap exists between the real bodies of the first two candles:
If the first candle is white, ensure an upside gap, signifying a bullish push.
If the first candle is black, ensure a downside gap, emphasizing continued bearish pressure.
Check the third candle's color, which must be opposite that of the first two. Its open should lie within the real body of the second candle, while its close should fall within the real body of the first candle, suggesting only a partial retracement against the ongoing trend.
Value interpretation:
A value of 100 indicates Upside Gap Three Methods pattern, signaling a bullish continuation.
A value of -100 indicates Downside Gap Three Methods pattern, signaling a bearish continuation.
A value of 0 indicates that no pattern was detected.

member.name: M:TALib.Candles.UpsideGapTwoCrows``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{System.Int32},System.Range@)
member.summary: Upside Gap Two Crows (Pattern Recognition)
member.param: A span of input open prices.
A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the output pattern type for each price bar.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Upside Gap Two Crows Pattern function identifies a bearish three-candle formation that generally manifests in an uptrend. It features a long white (bullish) candle, followed by two black (bearish) candles, with a gap appearing between the first candle's real body and the second candle's real body.
Calculation steps:
Confirm the first candle is white and long. Its real body length must surpass the average for BodyLong in CandleSettings.
Ensure the second candle is black and short, meeting or falling below the threshold specified by BodyShort. It must gap up relative to the first candle's real body, indicating a potential continuation of bullish pressure.
Verify the third candle is black, "engulfing" the real body of the second candle by opening above the second candle's open and closing below its close. The final close must remain above the first candle's close.
Value interpretation:
A value of -100 indicates the presence of an Upside Gap Two Crows pattern, signaling a bearish reversal.
A value of 0 indicates that no pattern was detected.

member.name: T:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType
member.summary: Types of candlestick pattern settings.
member.remarks: The settings are based on the parts of the candle and the common words indicating the length (short, long, very long).

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.BodyLong
member.summary: Real body is long when it's longer than the average of the 10 previous candles' real body.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.BodyVeryLong
member.summary: Real body is very long when it's longer than 3 times the average of the 10 previous candles' real body.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.BodyShort
member.summary: Real body is short when it's shorter than the average of the 10 previous candles' real bodies.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.BodyDoji
member.summary: Real body is like doji's body when it's shorter than 10% the average of the 10 previous candles' high-low range.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.ShadowLong
member.summary: Shadow is long when it's longer than the real body.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.ShadowVeryLong
member.summary: Shadow is very long when it's longer than 2 times the real body.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.ShadowShort
member.summary: Shadow is short when it's shorter than half the average of the 10 previous candles' sum of shadows.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.ShadowVeryShort
member.summary: Shadow is very short when it's shorter than 10% the average of the 10 previous candles' high-low range.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.Near
member.summary: When measuring distance between parts of candles or width of gaps. "near" means >=20% of the average of the 5 previous candles' high-low range"

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.Far
member.summary: When measuring distance between parts of candles or width of gaps. "far" means ">=60% of the average of the 5 previous candles' high-low range"

member.name: F:TALib.Core.CandleSettingType.Equal
member.summary: When measuring distance between parts of candles or width of gaps. "equal" means "≤5% of the average of the 5 previous candles' high-low range"

member.summary: The operation was successful.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.RetCode.BadParam
member.summary: The operation failed due to an invalid parameter.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.RetCode.OutOfRangeParam
member.summary: The operation failed due to an insufficient number of elements in the input data.

member.name: T:TALib.Core.UnstableFunc
member.summary: Represents unique identifiers for functions that utilize algorithms with "memories".

member.name: T:TALib.Core.UnstablePeriodSettings
member.summary: Provides settings for unstable periods for all functions. It allows configuring how many initial periods should be stripped off for functions with "memory", ensuring that their output stabilizes before being used.
member.remarks:
Many TA functions, such as the Exponential Moving Average (EMA), utilize algorithms that retain memory of previous data points. This can lead to variations in the output during the initial periods of calculation, which may not be desirable for certain applications, especially in walk-forward testing.
The class allows setting and retrieving the unstable period for individual TA functions. The unstable period is the number of initial periods that are disregarded to ensure that the function's output is stable.
By default, there is no unstable period set for any TA function. It is up to the consumer to determine the appropriate number of periods to strip off. The general guideline is to strip off as many periods as necessary to achieve consistent results.
Setting an unstable period affects all instances where the function is used, including composite functions that use the specified function internally. For example, setting an unstable period for an EMA will also affect the EMA calculations within the MACD function.

member.name: F:TALib.Core.UnstablePeriodSettings.UnstablePeriods
member.remarks: Initializes the default unstable period settings for all functions.

member.name: M:TALib.Core.UnstablePeriodSettings.Get(TALib.Core.UnstableFunc)
member.summary: Retrieves the unstable period for a specified function.
member.param: The identifier of the function.
member.returns: The number of periods to be stripped off. Returns zero if the identifier specified is .

member.name: M:TALib.Core.UnstablePeriodSettings.Set(TALib.Core.UnstableFunc,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the unstable period for a specified function.
member.remarks: To apply the change to all applicable functions, specify .
member.param: The identifier of the function.
Number of periods to be stripped off.

member.name: M:TALib.FunctionHelpers.CalcPriceOscillator``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32,System.Int32,TALib.Core.MAType,System.Span{``0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Рассчитывает ценовой осциллятор на основе разности/отношения двух скользящих средних. Поддерживает режимы вывода: абсолютные значения (Fast MA - Slow MA) или процентное отношение ((Fast MA - Slow MA)/Slow MA * 100).
member.typeparam: Тип данных с плавающей точкой (например, double)
member.param: Входные данные для расчета (например, цены закрытия)
Диапазон обрабатываемых данных в (начальный и конечный индексы). - Если не указан, обрабатывается весь массив .

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения осциллятора. - Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен). - Каждый элемент outReal[i] соответствует inReal[outRange.Start + i].

Диапазон индексов в , для которых рассчитаны валидные значения: - Start: индекс первого элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - End: индекс последнего элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - Гарантируется: End == inReal.GetUpperBound(0) (последний элемент входных данных), если расчет успешен. - Если данных недостаточно (например, длина меньше периода индикатора), возвращается [0, -1].
Период быстрой скользящей средней (должен быть меньше медленного периода)
Период медленной скользящей средней (должен быть больше быстрого периода)
Метод расчета скользящих средних (SMA, EMA, и др.)
Временный буфер для хранения промежуточных значений быстрой скользящей средней
Флаг режима вывода: - true — результат в процентах ((Fast MA - Slow MA)/Slow MA * 100) - false — абсолютная разность (Fast MA - Slow MA)
member.returns: Код возврата (успех/ошибка)

Диапазон индексов в , для которых рассчитаны валидные значения: - Start: индекс первого элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - End: индекс последнего элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - Гарантируется: End == inReal.GetUpperBound(0) (последний элемент входных данных), если расчет успешен. - Если данных недостаточно (например, длина меньше периода индикатора), возвращается [0, -1].
Период для расчета дисперсии (количество баров в окне)

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Add``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@)
member.summary: Векторное арифметическое сложение (Math Operators)
member.param: Первый набор входных значений.
Второй набор входных значений.
Диапазон обрабатываемых данных в и (начальный и конечный индексы). - Если не указан, обрабатываются все элементы входных массивов.

Массив, содержащий результаты поэлементного сложения. - Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен). - Каждый элемент outReal[i] соответствует inReal0[outRange.Start + i] + inReal1[outRange.Start + i].

Диапазон индексов во входных данных, для которых выполнены расчеты: - Start: индекс первого элемента, для которого есть результат. - End: индекс последнего элемента, для которого есть результат. - Гарантируется: End == inReal0.GetUpperBound(0) при успешном расчете.
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных (обычно или ), реализующий интерфейс .
member.returns: Код результата из . Возвращает при успешном расчете.
member.remarks:
Функция выполняет поэлементное сложение двух числовых рядов. Применяется для создания составных индикаторов или модификации сигналов.
Не генерирует торговые сигналы напрямую, но полезна для: - Построения пользовательских индикаторов - Комбинирования различных технических показателей - Корректировки сигналов в торговых стратегиях

member.remarks: Lookback период = 0 означает, что первое валидное значение доступно сразу для первого элемента входных данных.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Sub``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@)
member.summary: Векторная арифметическая операция вычитания (Математические операторы)
member.param: Первый набор входных значений.
Второй набор входных значений.
Диапазон обрабатываемых данных в и (начальный и конечный индексы). - Если не указан, обрабатывается весь массив и .

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения индикатора. - Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен). - Каждый элемент outReal[i] соответствует inReal0[outRange.Start + i].

Диапазон индексов в и , для которых рассчитаны валидные значения: - Start: индекс первого элемента и , имеющего валидное значение в . - End: индекс последнего элемента и , имеющего валидное значение в . - Гарантируется: End == inReal0.GetUpperBound(0) (последний элемент входных данных), если расчет успешен. - Если данных недостаточно (например, длина и меньше периода индикатора), возвращается [0, -1].
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных, обычно или , реализующий интерфейс .
member.returns: Значение , указывающее успешность или неудачу вычисления. Возвращает при успешном вычислении, или соответствующий код ошибки в противном случае.
member.remarks:
SUB вычитает один ряд данных из другого, что полезно для индикаторов спрэда или сравнительного анализа.
Функция является фундаментальной операцией в разработке пользовательских индикаторов. Интеграция её в стратегии парного трейдинга или межрыночного сравнения может дать инсайты относительной силы.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Sum``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Суммирование (MathOperators)
member.param: Входные данные для расчета индикатора (цены, другие индикаторы или другие временные ряды)
Диапазон обрабатываемых данных в (начальный и конечный индексы). - Если не указан, обрабатывается весь массив .

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения индикатора. - Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен). - Каждый элемент outReal[i] соответствует inReal[outRange.Start + i].

Диапазон индексов в , для которых рассчитаны валидные значения: - Start: индекс первого элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - End: индекс последнего элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - Гарантируется: End == inReal.GetUpperBound(0) (последний элемент входных данных), если расчет успешен. - Если данных недостаточно (например, длина меньше периода индикатора), возвращается [0, -1].
Период времени.
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных, обычно или , реализующий интерфейс .
member.returns: Значение , указывающее на успешность или неудачу расчета. Возвращает при успешном расчете, или соответствующий код ошибки в противном случае.
member.remarks:
SUM добавляет точки данных за определенный период, что полезно для накопительных расчетов или методов сглаживания.
Функция предоставляет скользящее суммирование, которое может использоваться в качестве базового значения для других расчетов или индикаторов. Его полезность заключается в создании пользовательских индикаторов, где накопленные данные информируют о тренде или импульсе.
Этапы расчета:
Инициализировать сумму значений за первый период времени.
Для каждого последующего периода обновлять сумму, добавляя новое значение и удаляя самое старое значение из суммы.
Сохранять рассчитанную сумму для каждого периода в выходном массиве.

member.param: Входные данные для расчета индикатора (цены, другие индикаторы или другие временные ряды)
Диапазон обрабатываемых данных в (начальный и конечный индексы). - Если не указан, обрабатывается весь массив .

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения индикатора. - Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен). - Каждый элемент outReal[i] соответствует inReal[outRange.Start + i].

Диапазон индексов в , для которых рассчитаны валидные значения: - Start: индекс первого элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - End: индекс последнего элемента , имеющего валидное значение в . - Гарантируется: End == inReal.GetUpperBound(0) (последний элемент входных данных), если расчет успешен. - Если данных недостаточно, возвращается [0, -1].

member.remarks:
ACos применяет функцию арккосинуса к каждой точке данных в серии, в основном для продвинутого математического моделирования, а не для стандартного технического анализа.
Функция редко используется отдельно для генерации сигналов. Может быть интегрирована в специализированные/проприетарные модели в сочетании с другими математическими преобразованиями.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Accbands``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Acceleration Bands (Overlap Studies) - Полосы ускорения
member.param: Массив входных максимальных цен.
Массив входных минимальных цен.
Массив входных цен закрытия.
Диапазон обрабатываемых данных во входных массивах (начальный и конечный индексы). - Если не указан, обрабатывается весь массив.
Массив для хранения рассчитанных значений верхней полосы.
Массив для хранения рассчитанных значений средней полосы.
Массив для хранения рассчитанных значений нижней полосы.
Диапазон индексов во входных данных, для которых рассчитаны валидные значения: - Start: индекс первого элемента с валидным значением. - End: индекс последнего элемента с валидным значением.
Период расчета (по умолчанию 20).
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных (обычно или ), реализующий интерфейс .
member.returns: Код результата из . Возвращает при успешном расчете.
member.remarks:
Полосы ускорения - индикатор волатильности для определения точек прорыва и силы тренда. Полосы динамически адаптируются к движению цены.
Может использоваться совместно с индикаторами импульса или тренда, такими как ADX или RSI для подтверждения сигналов.
Шаги расчета:
Расчет верхней и нижней полос для каждого периода:
Upper Band = High * (1 + 4 * (High - Low) / (High + Low)) Lower Band = Low * (1 - 4 * (High - Low) / (High + Low))
Расчет скользящей средней цены закрытия для средней полосы:
Middle Band = SMA(Close, Period)
Применение SMA для сглаживания верхней и нижней полос.
Интерпретация значений:
Прорыв цены выше верхней полосы указывает на сильный восходящий импульс.
Прорыв цены ниже нижней полосы указывает на сильный нисходящий импульс.
Средняя полоса служит базовой линией для определения тренда.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.AdOsc``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Осциллятор Chaikin A/D (индикаторы объема)
member.param: Массив входных цен High (максимумы).
Массив входных цен Low (минимумы).
Массив входных цен Close (закрытия).
Массив входных данных объема торгов.
Диапазон индексов для вычислений во входных данных.
Массив для сохранения рассчитанных значений осциллятора.
Диапазон индексов с валидными данными в выходном массиве.
Период для расчета быстрой экспоненциальной скользящей средней (EMA).
Период для расчета медленной экспоненциальной скользящей средней (EMA).
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных (float/double).
member.returns: Код результата выполнения ().
member.remarks:
Осциллятор Chaikin A/D измеряет импульс линии Накопления/Распределения, сравнивая краткосрочные и долгосрочные интервалы денежного потока.
Позволяет выявлять изменения покупательского/продавеческого давления до их проявления в ценовых данных. Может подтверждать тренды, выявленные по цене, или служить опережающим индикатором пробоев.
Этапы расчета:
Расчет линии Накопления/Распределения:
A/D Line = ((Close - Low) - (High - Close)) / (High - Low) * Volume
Расчет быстрой EMA (экспоненциальной скользящей средней) для линии A/D.
Расчет медленной EMA для линии A/D.
Осциллятор Chaikin A/D как разница между быстрой и медленной EMA:
AdOsc = EMA(Fast, A/D Line) - EMA(Slow, A/D Line)
Интерпретация значений:
Рост значений указывает на усиление покупательского давления (потенциальный рост цены).
Падение значений указывает на усиление продавеческого давления (потенциальное снижение цены).
Дивергенция между осциллятором и ценой сигнализирует о возможных разворотах тренда.

member.param: Период для быстрой EMA.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Adx``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Average Directional Movement Index (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Average Directional Movement Index is a momentum indicator that measures the strength of a trend without indicating its direction. It is derived from the Directional Movement indicators (+DI and -DI) and is commonly used in conjunction with them to evaluate the intensity of market trends.
The function can guide the selection of trend-following or range-based strategies. It is often combined with moving averages, oscillators, or support/resistance analysis to avoid false signals in low-trend-strength conditions.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the True Range (TR) and Directional Movement (DM) values:
TR = max(High - Low, abs(High - Previous Close), abs(Low - Previous Close)) +DM = High - Previous High (if positive and greater than Low - Previous Low, otherwise 0) -DM = Previous Low - Low (if positive and greater than High - Previous High, otherwise 0)
Smooth the TR, +DM, and -DM values over the specified time period using Wilder's smoothing technique.
Calculate the Directional Indicators (+DI and -DI):
+DI = 100 * (+DM / TR) -DI = 100 * (-DM / TR)
Calculate the Directional Movement Index (DX):
DX = 100 * abs(+DI - -DI) / (+DI + -DI)
Compute the ADX as a smoothed average of the DX values over the specified time period.
Value interpretation:
Values above 25 indicate a strong trend, while values below 20 suggest a weak or non-existent trend.
A rising value suggests a strengthening trend, while a falling ADX indicates a weakening trend.
The ADX does not indicate the direction of the trend; it measures only its strength.

member.summary: Returns the lookback period for Adx.
member.param: The time period.
member.returns: The number of periods required before the first output value can be calculated.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Adxr``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Average Directional Movement Index Rating (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Average Directional Movement Index Rating is a smoothed version of the ADX indicator, used to measure the strength of a trend. It is calculated as the average of the current ADX value and the ADX value from a previous period. The ADXR further smooths the ADX, making it less volatile and easier to interpret.
The function is commonly used in trend-following strategies to confirm trend strength and filter out periods of low volatility. It is less reactive to short-term price fluctuations, making it particularly useful for identifying longer-term trends.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the ADX values over the specified time period. Refer to the ADX function for details on the calculation.
For each ADX value, average it with the ADX value from a previous period (offset by the time period):
ADXR = (Current ADX + ADX from Previous Period) / 2
Value interpretation:
Values above 25 indicate a strong trend, while values below 20 suggest a weak or non-existent trend.
A rising value suggests a strengthening trend, while a falling value indicates a weakening trend.
Like ADX, the ADXR does not indicate the direction of the trend but measures its strength.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Apo``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32,System.Int32,TALib.Core.MAType)
member.summary: Absolute Price Oscillator (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period for calculating the fast moving average.
The time period for calculating the slow moving average.
The moving average type.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Absolute Price Oscillator is a momentum indicator that calculates the difference between two moving averages of an input series, typically the price. It is used to identify trends, momentum, and potential reversals in price movements.
The function can help identify early signs of trend reversals. It may be combined with volume indicators or volatility measures to provide additional confirmation.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the fast moving average of the input series using the specified fast period and moving average type.
Calculate the slow moving average of the input series using the specified slow period and moving average type.
Subtract the slow moving average from the fast moving average to compute the APO:
APO = Fast MA - Slow MA
Value interpretation:
A positive value indicates that the fast moving average is above the slow moving average, suggesting upward momentum.
A negative value indicates that the fast moving average is below the slow moving average, suggesting downward momentum.
Crossovers of the APO above or below the zero line can signal potential buy or sell opportunities, respectively.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Aroon``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Aroon (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated Aroon Down values.
A span to store the calculated Aroon Up values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
The Aroon indicator is a momentum-based indicator that measures the time between highs and lows over a specified time period to identify the strength and direction of a trend. It consists of two components: Aroon Up and Aroon Down, which are calculated separately.
The function is particularly useful for identifying trend reversals and assessing trend strength. It can also be used in conjunction with other technical indicators to confirm trading signals or filter out noise.
Calculation steps:
Identify the highest high and lowest low within the specified time period.
Calculate Aroon Up:
Aroon Up = 100 * (Time Period - Days Since Highest High) / Time Period
Calculate Aroon Down:
Aroon Down = 100 * (Time Period - Days Since Lowest Low) / Time Period
Value interpretation:
Values close to 100 indicate a strong upward trend, while values near 0 indicate no recent highs.
Values close to 100 indicate a strong downward trend, while values near 0 indicate no recent lows.
When Aroon Up crosses above Aroon Down, it may signal the beginning of an upward trend.
When Aroon Down crosses above Aroon Up, it may signal the beginning of a downward trend.

member.summary: Returns the lookback period for Aroon.
member.param: The time period.
member.returns: The number of periods required before the first output value can be calculated.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.AroonOsc``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Aroon Oscillator (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Aroon Oscillator is a momentum indicator that measures the difference between the Aroon Up and Aroon Down indicators to assess the strength and direction of a trend.
The function is useful for identifying trend strength and direction and can also signal potential reversals when crossing above or below the zero line. It is commonly used in conjunction with other technical indicators to improve the reliability of trading signals.
Calculation steps:
Identify the highest high and lowest low within the specified time period.
Calculate Aroon Up and Aroon Down:
Aroon Up = 100 * (Time Period - Days Since Highest High) / Time Period Aroon Down = 100 * (Time Period - Days Since Lowest Low) / Time Period
Calculate the Aroon Oscillator as the difference between Aroon Up and Aroon Down:
Aroon Oscillator = Aroon Up - Aroon Down
Value interpretation:
Positive values indicate that the Aroon Up is stronger than the Aroon Down, suggesting an upward trend.
Negative values indicate that the Aroon Down is stronger than the Aroon Up, suggesting a downward trend.
The closer the value is to +100 or -100, the stronger the respective trend.
Values around 0 suggest a lack of clear trend or a sideways market.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Atr``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Average True Range (Volatility Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Average True Range is a volatility indicator that measures the degree of price movement over a specified time period.
The function is widely used for setting stop-loss levels, managing position sizes, and assessing volatility conditions. It may be integrated with trend or momentum indicators to enhance risk management.
Calculation steps:
Compute the True Range (TR), which is the greatest of the following:
TR = max[(High - Low), abs(High - Previous Close), abs(Low - Previous Close)]
For the first ATR value, calculate the simple average of the TR values over the specified time period.
For subsequent ATR values, use Wilder's smoothing method:
ATR = [(Previous ATR * (Time Period - 1)) + Current TR] / Time Period
Value interpretation:
A higher value indicates higher market volatility.
A lower value suggests reduced volatility.
ATR does not indicate the direction of price movement but reflects the degree of volatility over the specified period.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.AvgDev``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Average Deviation (Price Transform)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Average Deviation calculates how far each data point deviates from the mean, serving as a measure of volatility. It provides insights into the variability or volatility of a dataset.
The function can help assess market stability or variability. Incorporating it into strategies with trend or momentum indicators may refine volatility-informed decisions.
Calculation steps:
Compute the mean (average) of the values over the specified time period:
Mean = Sum of values / Time Period
Calculate the absolute deviation of each value from the mean:
Deviation[i] = abs(Value[i] - Mean)
Compute the average of these deviations to get the AvgDev:
AvgDev = Sum of Deviations / Time Period
Value interpretation:
A higher value indicates greater variability.
A lower value indicates more stability.

member.remarks:
Average Price is a simple price transform that calculates the arithmetic mean of the open, high, low, and close prices for a given range. It provides a single value representing the average price of a security over a period.
This function is useful for smoothing out price fluctuations and obtaining a representative price for analysis. Combining it with moving averages or oscillators may assist in identifying fair value zones or mean-reversion opportunities.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Bbands``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,TALib.Core.MAType)
member.summary: Полосы Боллинджера (Скользящие исследования)
member.param: Входные данные для расчета индикатора (цены, другие индикаторы или другие временные ряды)

Диапазон обрабатываемых данных в (начальный и конечный индексы).
- Если не указан, обрабатывается весь массив .

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения верхней полосы.
- Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен).
- Каждый элемент outRealUpperBand[i] соответствует inReal[outRange.Start + i].

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения средней полосы.
- Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен).
- Каждый элемент outRealMiddleBand[i] соответствует inReal[outRange.Start + i].

Массив, содержащий ТОЛЬКО валидные значения нижней полосы.
- Длина массива равна outRange.End - outRange.Start + 1 (если outRange корректен).
- Каждый элемент outRealLowerBand[i] соответствует inReal[outRange.Start + i].

Диапазон индексов в , для которых рассчитаны валидные значения:
- Start: индекс первого элемента , имеющего валидное значение в , и .
- End: индекс последнего элемента , имеющего валидное значение в , и .
- Гарантируется: End == inReal.GetUpperBound(0) (последний элемент входных данных), если расчет успешен.
- Если данных недостаточно (например, длина меньше периода индикатора), возвращается [0, -1].
Период расчета.

Множитель стандартного отклонения для верхней полосы:
Большие значения увеличивают расстояние от средней полосы, снижая чувствительность к незначительным колебаниям цены.
Меньшие значения сокращают расстояние, повышая реакцию на изменения цены.
Значения выше 5 редко используются из-за потери практической значимости.

Множитель стандартного отклонения для нижней полосы:
Большие значения увеличивают расстояние от средней полосы, снижая вероятность сигналов перепроданности.
Меньшие значения сокращают расстояние, повышая чувствительность к снижению цены.
Значения выше 5 редко используются из-за потери практической значимости.
Тип скользящей средней.
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных (обычно или ), реализующий интерфейс .
member.returns:
Код результата .
Возвращает при успешном расчете или код ошибки.
member.remarks:
Полосы Боллинджера — индикатор на основе волатильности, использующий скользящую среднюю и стандартные отклонения для формирования верхней и нижней "полос" вокруг цены. Полосы расширяются/сужаются при изменении волатильности, предоставляя информацию о потенциальных зонах перекупленности/перепроданности, периодах консолидации и прорывах.
Используется в торговых стратегиях для идентификации возможностей прорыва, продолжения тренда или разворота.
Этапы расчета:
Средняя полоса = скользящая средняя входных значений за указанный период.
Стандартное отклонение входных значений за тот же период.
Верхняя/нижняя полосы рассчитываются по формулам:
Upper Band = Middle Band + (Standard Deviation * NbDevUp) Lower Band = Middle Band - (Standard Deviation * NbDevDn)
Где:
Middle Band — средняя полоса (скользящая средняя)
Standard Deviation — стандартное отклонение
NbDevUp/NbDevDn — множители для верхней/нижней полос
Интерпретация значений:
Приближение цены к верхней полосе указывает на возможную перекупленность (риск коррекции).
Приближение цены к нижней полосе указывает на возможную перепроданность (потенциал роста).
Сужение полос (низкая волатильность) предшествует прорывам. Расширение (высокая волатильность) — подтверждает тренд.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Beta``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Beta (Statistic Functions)
member.param: A span of input security or stock prices.
A span of input benchmark or market prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Beta function calculates the beta coefficient, which measures the volatility of a security relative to a benchmark index.
The function can be used in risk management and portfolio selection. Combining it with other risk measures or normalization techniques may optimize instrument choices.
Calculation formula:
Beta = Covariance(Security, Market) / Variance(Market)
where the covariance and variance are derived from the percentage changes in the security's and market's prices over a specified time period.
Value interpretation:
A value of 1 indicates that the security's price moves with the market.
A value greater than 1 suggests that the security is more volatile than the market.
A value less than 1 indicates that the security is less volatile than the market.

member.remarks:
Balance of Power is a momentum indicator that measures the strength of buyers versus sellers by comparing the close price relative to the open price, normalized by the trading range.
The function can be integrated with volume-based or price-action indicators to detect subtle sentiment changes and reinforce signals from other tools.
Calculation formula:
BOP = (Close - Open) / (High - Low)
Value interpretation:
A positive value indicates buyer dominance, where the close price is higher than the open price.
A negative value indicates seller dominance, where the close price is lower than the open price.
A value near zero suggests equilibrium between buyers and sellers.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Cci``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Commodity Channel Index (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Commodity Channel Index is a momentum indicator that measures the deviation of the typical price (average of high, low, and close) from its moving average over a specified time period.
It is commonly used to identify overbought and oversold conditions, as well as potential trend reversals. Combining it with trend indicators can help avoid reacting against strong prevailing trends.
Calculation steps:
Compute the Typical Price (TP) for each period:
TP = (High + Low + Close) / 3
Calculate the moving average (MA) of the Typical Price over the specified time period.
Compute the Mean Deviation of the Typical Price from the moving average.
Calculate the CCI:
CCI = (TP - MA) / (0.015 * Mean Deviation)
Value interpretation:
A positive value indicates that the price is above the moving average, suggesting bullish momentum.
A negative value indicates that the price is below the moving average, suggesting bearish momentum.
Values above +100 or below -100 are typically used as thresholds for overbought or oversold conditions.

member.param: The time period.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Cmo``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Chande Momentum Oscillator (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Chande Momentum Oscillator is a momentum indicator that measures the difference between the sum of gains and losses over a specified time period, normalized by their total. It is similar to RSI, but CMO considers both the upward and downward momentum simultaneously in its calculation.
The function can detect momentum shifts. Incorporating it with trend confirmation tools may improve accuracy in timing decisions. The function is particularly useful in identifying overbought and oversold conditions and in confirming trends when used with other indicators.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the gains and losses between consecutive price values over the specified time period.
Compute the sum of gains and the sum of losses.
Calculate the CMO:
CMO = 100 * (Sum of Gains - Sum of Losses) / (Sum of Gains + Sum of Losses)
Value interpretation:
A positive value indicates upward momentum, suggesting bullish conditions.
A negative value indicates downward momentum, suggesting bearish conditions.
Values near zero suggest a lack of significant momentum in either direction.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Correl``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Pearson's Correlation Coefficient (r) (Statistic Functions)
member.param: A span of input values for the first dataset.
A span of input values for the second dataset.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Pearson's Correlation Coefficient (r) measures the linear correlation between two datasets, showing how closely they move together.
The function is useful for portfolio construction, pair strategies, and diversification. It can be paired with relative strength or spread indicators to identify correlation breakdowns or convergences.
Calculation steps:
Compute the sums of the two datasets and their respective squares over the specified time period.
Compute the product of the datasets for each time period and calculate the sum of these products.
Calculate the covariance and the standard deviations of the datasets.
Divide the covariance by the product of the standard deviations to compute the correlation coefficient.
Value interpretation:
-1 value indicates a perfect negative linear relationship.
0 indicates no linear relationship.
1 value indicates a perfect positive linear relationship.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Dema``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Double Exponential Moving Average (Overlap Studies)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Double Exponential Moving Average is designed to reduce the lag associated with traditional moving averages by combining a single exponential moving average with the EMA of that EMA (commonly referred to as EMA2).
This calculation results in a smoother average that reacts faster to price changes, making it useful for identifying trends and reversals with reduced lag. The function can improve responsiveness in trend-following strategies. Combining it with oscillators may help confirm signals and minimize delays.
Calculation formula:
DEMA = 2 * EMA(t, period) - EMA(EMA(t, period), period)

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Dx``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Directional Movement Index (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input high prices.
A span of input low prices.
A span of input close prices.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Directional Movement Index is a technical indicator used to measure trend strength in a market.
It is part of the Average Directional Index (ADX) calculation and provides the foundation for understanding positive (PlusDI) and negative (MinusDI) directional movements. Using it alongside trend or volume indicators can improve the identification of strong directional movements.
Calculation steps:
Compute the True Range (TR), Positive Directional Movement (+DM), and Negative Directional Movement (-DM).
Calculate smoothed averages for +DM, -DM, and TR over the specified time period using Wilder's smoothing technique.
Derive +DI and -DI using the smoothed values:
+DI = (+DM / TR) * 100 -DI = (-DM / TR) * 100
Calculate the DX:
DX = ((|+DI - -DI|) / (+DI + -DI)) * 100
Value interpretation:
A high value (e.g., above 25) typically signals a strong trend.
A low value (e.g., below 20) indicates a weak or no trend.
The DX alone does not indicate trend direction; instead, the +DI and -DI provide direction insights.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Ema``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Exponential Moving Average (Overlap Studies)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Exponential Moving Average is a type of moving average that gives more weight to recent data points, making it more responsive to new information compared to Simple Moving Average.
The function is commonly used in technical analysis to identify trends and generate trading signals. It is particularly useful in tracking short-term price movements or momentum in financial markets.
Calculation steps:
Compute the initial SMA (Simple Moving Average) over the specified time period to use as the first EMA value.
Calculate the smoothing constant:
Smoothing Constant (k) = 2 / (Time Period + 1)
Update the EMA for subsequent periods using the formula:
EMA = (Current Price - Previous EMA) * k + Previous EMA

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.HtDcPeriod``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@)
member.summary: Hilbert Transform - Dominant Cycle Period (Cycle Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Hilbert Transform - Dominant Cycle Period identifies the dominant cycle length in market data. It applies a series of transformations to identify periodic patterns and their dominant frequency.
The function is used in advanced technical analysis to identify cycles in financial time series data, helping to determine market trends and timing for entry or exit positions. The function can be integrated into cycle-based approaches to time entries or exits.
Calculation steps:
Smooth the input data using a weighted moving average (WMA) to reduce noise while preserving the underlying signal.
Apply the Hilbert Transform to compute in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components for odd and even price bars.
Calculate the arctangent of Q and I components to compute phase changes between successive price bars.
Use the phase change to estimate the instantaneous period of the dominant cycle.
Apply a smoothing factor to stabilize the calculated period and reduce the impact of noise and outliers.
Value interpretation:
The output represents the dominant cycle period in the data.
A smaller period indicates faster market cycles, while a larger period signals slower cycles.
Limitations:
The function is more effective in cyclical or ranging markets and may produce unreliable results in strong trending conditions.
The output is sensitive to noisy data; smoothing techniques, such as WMA, help mitigate this.

member.returns: The number of periods required before the first output value can be calculated.
member.remarks: See MamaLookback for an explanation of the "32"

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.HtDcPhase``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@)
member.summary: Hilbert Transform - Dominant Cycle Phase (Cycle Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Hilbert Transform - Dominant Cycle Phase determines the phase of the dominant price cycle, locating the current position within the cycle. This phase angle provides insights into the position within the cycle, which can be used for timing and trend analysis.
The function is useful in identifying cycles and their phases in financial data. It helps in identifying overbought and oversold conditions and potential reversals in price movements. The function can enhance timing when combined with HT DC Period or other cycle tools. Adding trend and momentum measures can refine decisions further.
Calculation steps:
Smooth the input prices using a weighted moving average (WMA) to remove noise and stabilize the data.
Use the Hilbert Transform to compute the in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components for even and odd price bars. These components form the basis of the phase calculation.
Compute the real and imaginary parts of the dominant cycle phase using trigonometric operations over the smoothed prices.
Derive the phase angle from the real and imaginary parts. Adjust the phase angle for small imaginary components and account for one-bar lags introduced by the WMA.
Perform final phase adjustments to ensure the result is within the expected range.
Value interpretation:
A value provides the current position within a market cycle.
A rising value may indicate the beginning of a bullish trend, while a falling phase may signal bearish trends.
A falling value may signal bearish trends.
Limitations:
The function is more effective in cyclical or ranging markets and may produce unreliable results in strong trending conditions.
The output is sensitive to noisy data; smoothing techniques, such as WMA, help mitigate this.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.HtPhasor``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Range@)
member.summary: Hilbert Transform - Phasor Components (Cycle Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated "in-phase" component values.
A span to store the calculated "quadrature" component values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Hilbert Transform - Phasor Components is a technical indicator that decomposes price data into its in-phase and quadrature components. These components represent the real and imaginary parts of the signal, respectively, and are essential for analyzing cyclic properties of price data.
The function is generally used in cycle-focused analysis. Integrating it with conventional trend or momentum indicators can validate cyclical signals. The function is useful in identifying cycles and their phases in financial data, enabling to anticipate price reversals or continuations.
Calculation steps:
Smooth the input prices using a weighted moving average (WMA) to minimize noise and stabilize the underlying data.
Apply the Hilbert Transform to determine the in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components for both even and odd bars.
Compute the real and imaginary parts of the phase using trigonometric calculations applied to the smoothed data.
Derive the phase angle from the real and imaginary parts, adjusting for small imaginary values and any WMA-induced lag.
Perform final adjustments to the phase angle to ensure it fits within the expected range of values.
Value interpretation:
The in-phase component represents the price data's position within a cycle.
The quadrature component captures the signal's delay or lag relative to the cycle.
By plotting these components on a polar graph, the cyclic behavior can be observed, and the phase shifts can be identified, which may indicate trend reversals or transitions.
Limitations:
The function is most effective in markets with cyclic behavior and may produce unreliable results in trending or highly volatile markets.
The accuracy of the components depends on the quality of the smoothed input data.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.HtSine``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Range@)
member.summary: Hilbert Transform - SineWave (Cycle Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the sine wave values.
A span to store the leading sine wave values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Hilbert Transform - SineWave identifies and visualizes the cyclic behavior of time series data by calculating the sine and leading sine components of the dominant cycle. These components are particularly useful for analyzing market trends and detecting potential reversals.
This function can assist in timing entries or exits in cyclic conditions. Confirming identified turning points with trend analysis, oscillators like RSI, or cycle-based tools such as HT DC Period can improve reliability.
Calculation steps:
Smooth the input prices using a weighted moving average (WMA) to reduce noise and ensure smoother transitions.
Apply the Hilbert Transform to extract in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components for even and odd bars, capturing cycle properties.
Compute the dominant cycle phase (DCPhase) using the I and Q components. This provides the current position in the cycle.
Calculate the sine of the DCPhase (outSine) and the leading sine (outLeadSine), which is the phase shifted by 45 degrees. These values provide insights into the cyclic movements and potential turning points.
Value interpretation*:
The sine wave represents the current phase of the dominant cycle.
The leading sine wave is the sine wave shifted forward by 45 degrees, helping identify early phase transitions.
When the sine wave and leading sine wave intersect, it may indicate a potential cycle peak or trough, signaling possible market reversals.
Limitations:
The function is most effective in cyclic markets and may produce unreliable signals in trending or highly volatile markets.
It is sensitive to noise in the input data; therefore, appropriate smoothing is critical for accurate results.

The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Hilbert Transform - Instantaneous Trendline is a cycle indicator designed to calculate a smooth trendline using the Hilbert Transform. It removes noise and provides an immediate trend representation by combining recent smoothed data points and extrapolating based on dominant cycles.
The function can be combined with ADX or MACD to ensure that changes in the trendline align with broader conditions, reducing the risk of acting on false signals.
Calculation steps:
Smooth the input prices using a weighted moving average (WMA) to reduce noise and ensure smoother transitions.
Apply the Hilbert Transform to extract the in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components, which are used to determine the cycle properties.
Compute the dominant cycle period using the I and Q components to estimate the cycle length dynamically.
Compute the trendline using a weighted moving average of the smoothed values over the dominant cycle period.
Store the calculated trendline values in the output span for visualization or further analysis.
Value interpretation:
The trendline provides a smooth representation of the market trend, filtering out short-term volatility.
Limitations:
The function is primarily effective in trending markets and may underperform in highly cyclic or volatile environments.
The algorithm assumes the presence of a dominant cycle, so markets lacking cyclic behavior may result in misleading trends.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.HtTrendMode``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{System.Int32},System.Range@)
member.summary: Hilbert Transform - Trend vs Cycle Mode (Cycle Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated mode values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Hilbert Transform - Trend vs Cycle Mode is a cycle indicator that determines whether the market is in a trending state or a cyclic state. It achieves this by analyzing dominant cycles in the data and comparing their properties against predefined thresholds.
The function can help select appropriate indicators for the current market mode. In trend mode, trend-following tools may be favored; in cycle mode, oscillators may yield better results.
Calculation steps:
Smooth the input prices using a weighted moving average (WMA) to reduce noise and emphasize key trends.
Apply the Hilbert Transform to extract in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components, which are used to calculate the dominant cycle properties.
Compute the dominant cycle phase (DC Phase) and smooth the phase over successive iterations.
Generate sine and leading sine values using the smoothed DC phase for cycle mode detection.
Analyze crossings and deviations of the sine wave components to determine whether the series is in a trend or cycle mode.
Value interpretation:
A trend mode (1) is indicated when the market shows sustained directional movement, with cycles playing a secondary role.
A cycle mode (0) is indicated when the market oscillates within a well-defined range, and dominant cycles can be observed.
Limitations:
This function is less effective in noisy or volatile markets where dominant cycles are hard to detect.
False positives may occur in markets transitioning between trending and cyclic behavior.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Kama``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average (Overlap Studies)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average is a moving average designed to adapt to market volatility. It adjusts its smoothing factor based on the efficiency ratio, which is calculated as the ratio of price direction to price volatility over a specified period. This allows KAMA to be more responsive during trends and less sensitive during consolidations.
The function can reduce noise and whipsaws. Due to its adaptive nature, KAMA can reduce lag compared to traditional moving averages, making it useful for identifying trends and avoiding false signals.
Calculation steps:
Compute the Efficiency Ratio (ER):
ER = Abs(PriceChange) / Sum(Abs(PriceChange over TimePeriod))
where PriceChange is the difference between the current price and the price `TimePeriod` ago.
Compute the Smoothing Constant (SC):
SC = [ER * (FastestSC - SlowestSC) + SlowestSC]^2
where FastestSC and SlowestSC are constants typically derived from a short and long smoothing period, respectively.
Apply the SC to calculate the KAMA:
KAMA = PreviousKAMA + SC * (Price - PreviousKAMA)
Value interpretation:
A rising KAMA indicates an uptrend, particularly when it reacts swiftly to price increases.
A flat or declining KAMA suggests a consolidation or downtrend.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.LinearReg``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Линейная регрессия (статистические функции)
member.param: Массив входных значений для анализа.
Диапазон индексов, определяющий участок данных для расчета.
Массив для сохранения результатов расчета.
Диапазон индексов с валидными данными в выходном массиве.
Период расчета (по умолчанию 14).
member.typeparam: Числовой тип данных (например, float или double), реализующий интерфейс .
member.returns: Код возврата : при успешном расчете, иначе код ошибки.
member.remarks:
Функция строит линию тренда методом наименьших квадратов для заданного периода.
Результат показывает прогнозируемое значение на последнем баре периода, что помогает определить направление тренда.
Этапы расчета:
Вычисление сумм: - X (индексы элементов), - X² (квадраты индексов), - X*Y (произведение индексов и значений).
Расчет наклона (m) по формуле: m = (nΣXY - ΣXΣY) / (nΣX² - (ΣX)²)
Расчет смещения (b) по формуле: b = (ΣY - mΣX) / n
Прогноз на последнем баре периода: y = b + m*(n-1)
Интерпретация:
Рост значений → восходящий тренд
Падение значений → нисходящий тренд
Горизонтальная линия → отсутствие тренда

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.LinearRegAngle``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Linear Regression Angle (Statistic Functions)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Linear Regression Angle calculates the angle of the slope of the best-fit line for a series of data points over a specified period. It provides a perspective on the direction and magnitude of the trend in degrees, helping to identify trend strength and direction.
The function can suggest the strength of a trend. Confirming with ADX or volume indicators may reduce misinterpretation of minor price changes as significant moves.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the sums of X values (index positions), squared X values, and the product of X and Y values (input values) over the specified period.
Compute the slope (m) of the regression line using the formula:
m = (n * Sum(XY) - Sum(X) * Sum(Y)) / (n * Sum(X^2) - (Sum(X))^2)
where n is the time period.
Convert the slope (m) into an angle in degrees using the arctangent function:
Angle = RadiansToDegrees(Atan(m))
Value interpretation:
A positive angle indicates an uptrend, where prices are increasing.
A negative angle indicates a downtrend, where prices are decreasing.
A near-zero angle suggests a lack of significant trend in the data over the period.
The greater the absolute value of the angle, the stronger the trend.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.LinearRegIntercept``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Linear Regression Intercept (Statistic Functions)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Linear Regression Intercept calculates the y-intercept of the best-fit line for a series of data points over a specified period. It represents the value of the line when the x-value (index) is zero, offering insight into the baseline level of the data.
It can be used in conjunction with the slope to better understand the data's trend characteristics. The function can serve as a reference point. Combining it with other regression-based metrics or price patterns may offer richer insights.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the sums of X values (index positions), squared X values, and the product of X and Y values (input values) over the specified period.
Compute the slope (m) of the regression line using the formula:
m = (n * Sum(XY) - Sum(X) * Sum(Y)) / (n * Sum(X^2) - (Sum(X))^2)
where n is the time period.
Calculate the y-intercept (b) of the regression line using the formula:
b = (Sum(Y) - m * Sum(X)) / n
where Sum(Y) is the sum of the input values, and Sum(X) is the sum of index positions.
Value interpretation:
The y-intercept indicates the starting level of the data series relative to the regression line.
Changes in the intercept over time can signal shifts in the baseline level of the data.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Ma``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32,TALib.Core.MAType)
member.summary: Moving Average (Overlap Studies)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period.
The moving average type.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Moving Average function calculates the average of a series of data points over a specified period, smoothing out fluctuations to highlight trends. Various types of moving averages are supported, allowing for different smoothing techniques to cater to different analytical needs.
Supported moving average types via :
SMA (Simple Moving Average): A straightforward average of values over the specified period.
EMA (Exponential Moving Average): Assigns more weight to recent data, making it more responsive to changes.
WMA (Weighted Moving Average): Weights data points linearly, with the most recent data having the highest weight.
DEMA (Double Exponential Moving Average): A composite average designed to reduce lag.
TEMA (Triple Exponential Moving Average): Further reduces lag while smoothing data.
TRIMA (Triangular Moving Average): A double-smoothing technique.
KAMA (Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average): Adjusts responsiveness based on market volatility.
MAMA (MESA Adaptive Moving Average): Adapts to market cycles.
T3 (T3 Moving Average): A smooth moving average with reduced lag.
Value interpretation:
A rising moving average indicates an uptrend.
A falling moving average suggests a downtrend.
Crossovers of different moving averages (e.g., short-term and long-term) can indicate buy or sell signals.

member.name: M:TALib.Functions.Macd``1(System.ReadOnlySpan{``0},System.Range,System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Span{``0},System.Range@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moving Average Convergence/Divergence (Momentum Indicators)
member.param: A span of input values.
The range of indices that determines the portion of data to be calculated within the input spans.
A span to store the calculated MACD line values.
A span to store the calculated Signal line values.
A span to store the calculated MACD Histogram values.
The range of indices representing the valid data within the output spans.
The time period for calculating the fast moving average.
The time period for calculating the slow moving average.
The time period for calculating the Signal line.
member.typeparam: The numeric data type, typically or , implementing the interface.
member.returns: A value indicating the success or failure of the calculation. Returns on successful calculation, or an appropriate error code otherwise.
member.remarks:
Moving Average Convergence Divergence is a trend-following momentum indicator that shows the relationship between two moving averages of a security's price. It compares two EMAs to detect momentum shifts and potential trend reversals.
The function is widely recognized and often used with Rsi or Bollinger Bands for signal confirmation. Observing divergences and crossovers can aid in recognizing market changes.
Calculation steps:
Calculate the fast exponential moving average (EMA) of the input values over the specified `FastPeriod`.
Calculate the slow EMA of the input values over the specified `SlowPeriod`.
Compute the MACD line as the difference between the fast EMA and the slow EMA:
MACD = EMA(FastPeriod) - EMA(SlowPeriod)
Calculate the Signal line as the EMA of the MACD line over the specified `SignalPeriod`.
Compute the MACD Histogram as the difference between the MACD line and the Signal line:
MACDHist = MACD - Signal
Value interpretation:
A positive MACD line indicates upward momentum, while a negative MACD line indicates downward momentum.
The Signal line is used to identify potential buy or sell signals, with a bullish crossover occurring when the MACD line crosses above the Signal line, and a bearish crossover occurring when the MACD line crosses below the Signal line.
The MACD Histogram reflects the strength of momentum, with larger bars indicating stronger momentum in the direction of the MACD line and shrinking bars signaling a potential reversal or weakening momentum.

The choice of moving average types (e.g., SMA, EMA) for the fast, slow, and Signal lines affects the indicator's sensitivity. The function can be adapted to suit certain assets or volatility conditions. Combining it with volume indicators may strengthen momentum-based signals.

Compute the slow moving average using the specified and .

Value interpretation:
A positive MACD line indicates upward momentum, while a negative MACD line indicates downward momentum.
The Signal line is used to identify potential buy or sell signals, with a bullish crossover occurring when the MACD line crosses above the Signal line, and a bearish crossover occurring when the MACD line crosses below the Signal line.
The MACD Histogram reflects the strength of momentum, with larger bars indicating stronger momentum in the direction of the MACD line and shrinking bars signaling a potential reversal or weakening momentum.

The Signal line is used to identify potential buy or sell signals, with a bullish crossover occurring when the MACD line crosses above the Signal line, and a bearish crossover occurring when the MACD line crosses below the Signal line.
The MACD Histogram reflects the strength of momentum, with larger bars indicating stronger momentum in the direction of the MACD line and shrinking bars signaling a potential reversal or weakening momentum.
